original_table_html:
A. Consumer marketing channels B. Business marketing channels
Using direct channels, a company sells directly to consumers (no surprise there!). Examples: GEICO and Amway. Using indirect channels, the company uses one or more levels of intermediaries to help bring its products to final buyers. Examples: most of the things you buy—everything from toothpaste to cameras to cars.
Producer Producer Producer Producer Producer Producer
Retailer Wholesaler Business distributor Manufacturer’s representatives or sales branch
Retailer Business distributor Business distributor
Consumer Consumer Consumer Business customer Business customer Business customer
Channel 1 Channel 2 Channel 3 Channel 1 Channel 2 Channel 3
summary_markdown: This table outlines two primary categories of marketing channels: Consumer marketing channels and Business marketing channels. Consumer marketing channels are further divided into direct channels, where a company sells directly to consumers (e.g., GEICO, Amway), and indirect channels, which involve one or more intermediaries. Indirect consumer channels can include a producer selling to a retailer who then sells to the consumer (Channel 2), or a producer selling to a wholesaler who then sells to a retailer, who finally sells to the consumer (Channel 3). Business marketing channels primarily utilize indirect channels, involving intermediaries such as business distributors, manufacturer's representatives, or sales branches to reach business customers. These channels can involve a producer selling directly to a business distributor who then sells to a business customer (Channel 2), or a producer selling to a business distributor who then sells to another business distributor, who finally sells to the business customer (Channel 3).
